entry.title: Adult Resilience Scale Client Report
entry.content:
John Sample
11.06.2021

Adult Resilience Scale
Client Report

{% include ars/header.html %}

Definition of
Resilience

Many people have encountered an adverse experience at some point in their lives. Yet, some bounce back quickly while others endure the negativity for a longer period. A distinguishing factor between these people is their level of resilience.

Resilience has been widely defined as the ability to adapt to the changing environment and to bounce back from adversity and personal setbacks. Resilience has also been recognised as a measure of stress and the ability to cope with negative events, and can thus be defined as the personal qualities that enable an individual to thrive in difficult circumstances.

Research suggests that resilient people adapt more successfully in response to major life events and traumatic experiences (Sarkar & Fletcher, 2014). Research also shows that resilience is not necessarily related to personality or intelligence (Carver & Connor-Smith, 2010).

Interpreting the Adult Resilience Scale Scores

This report is a confidential summary of the candidate’s responses to the Adult Resilience Scale, and provides descriptions to interpret the scores. The Adult Resilience Scale measures five dimensions of resilience and provides an overall Total Resilience Score. When interpreting the candidate’s results, it is important to remember that scores are neither good nor bad, and should be used as development opportunities.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="1" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Model of Resilience

The five dimensions of resilience as measured in the Adult Resilience Scale are as follows:

Threat Perception

Awareness of potential or actual threat and ability to formulate a plan.

Adjustment

Ability to adjust when unexpected events cause disruption.

Decision Making

Ability to make clear decisions during stressful situations.

Coping

Capacity to deal with stressful events and ability to return to normal routine.

Recovery

Speed of returning to normal activity after challenging situations.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="2" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Results for John Sample

Overview

{% include ars/result-bar.html title="Total Resilience" color="navy" display_score="282" max_score="300" percentage="100" simple="yes" extra_classes="mb-12" %} {% include ars/result-bar.html title="Threat Perception" color="purple" display_score="39" max_score="60" percentage="60" simple="yes" extra_classes="mb-12" %} {% include ars/result-bar.html title="Adjustment" color="orange" display_score="30" max_score="60" percentage="40" simple="yes" extra_classes="mb-12" %} {% include ars/result-bar.html title="Decision Making" color="green" display_score="50" max_score="90" percentage="20" simple="yes" extra_classes="mb-12" %} {% include ars/result-bar.html title="Coping" color="fuchsia" display_score="80" max_score="90" percentage="80" simple="yes" extra_classes="mb-12" %} {% include ars/result-bar.html title="Recovery" color="yellow" display_score="80" max_score="90" percentage="80" simple="yes" extra_classes="mb-12" %}
{% include ars/footer.html page_number="3" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Dimensions and Intervals

Total Resilience

  • Ability to adapt.
  • Time needed to bounce back from adversity.
  • Capacity to cope with stress.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="navy" display_score="282" max_score="300" percentage="100" simple="yes" extra_classes="mt-2 mb-8" %}
Very High Range

This level of resilience indicates an exceptional level of ability to adapt to the changing environment and to bounce back from adversity and personal setbacks. Individuals with this level of resilience also have a very high capacity to cope with stress.

Threat Perception

  • Perceptive ability or situational awareness.
  • Awareness of potential or actual threat.
  • Ability to formulate a plan to continue.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="purple" display_score="39" max_score="60" percentage="60" simple="yes" extra_classes="mt-2 mb-8" %}
Average Range

Individuals with this level of threat perception have an average awareness of the environment and of potentially stressful situations. Individuals have the capacity to gradually work out a way forward.

Adjustment

  • Ability to adjust when unexpected events cause disruption.
  • Assessment of recovery options.
  • Flexibility and openness to new circumstances.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="orange" display_score="30" max_score="60" percentage="40" simple="yes" extra_classes="mt-2 mb-8" %}
Low Range

This level of adjustment capacity indicates a low ability to continue in the face of difficult circumstances. Individuals have limited ability to assess recovery options and are rarely flexible or open to new circumstances.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="4" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Decision Making

  • Ability to decide on recovery actions.
  • Capacity to make good decisions under pressure.
  • Capacity to make clear decisions in stressful events.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="green" display_score="50" max_score="90" percentage="20" simple="yes" extra_classes="mt-2 mb-8" %}
Very Low Range

Individuals at this level of decision making have very limited ability to make good decisions under pressure and to determine recovery actions in the face of difficult circumstances. They have a poor ability to make clear decisions when in stressful situations. Individuals find it difficult to assess the available recovery options and to choose the best one.

Coping

  • Capacity to deal with difficult issues.
  • Ability to put stressful events into perspective.
  • Capacity to activate coping mechanisms in a stressful event.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="fuchsia" display_score="80" max_score="90" percentage="80" simple="yes" extra_classes="mt-2 mb-8" %}
High Range

This level of coping capacity indicates a significant ability to deal with difficult issues as they arise, as well as a high capacity to put stressful events into perspective. Individuals operate recovery coping mechanisms and accept that a change in approach or strategy is required, so that stressful events are less likely to have a negative impact. Individuals may find it easier than others to act on decisions when under pressure and can easily apply the chosen solution to the problem.

Recovery

  • Ability to plan effectively.
  • Speed of self-management after a stressful event.
  • Return to healthy self after a stressful event.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="yellow" display_score="80" max_score="90" percentage="80" simple="yes" extra_classes="mt-2 mb-8" %}
High Range

This level of recovery capacity indicates a strong ability to plan effectively and to return to normal activity quickly after hardship or negative situations.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="5" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Adult Resilience Scale and Bell Curve Distribution

A bell curve is the informal name of a graph that depicts a normal probability distribution. The raw scores on the Adult Resilience Scale are best viewed in the below bell curve distribution. The bell curve represents a ‘normal distribution’ of the general population. A normal distribution has the average (or mean) centred and an equal distribution above and below average like the curve below. The bell curve assumes there is an equivalent number of people above and below average, and a very small number of people two standard deviations above and below the average (mean).

The raw scores on the Adult Resilience Scale are converted to mean (average) scores and standard deviations across five intervals ranging from Very Low, Low, Average, High, and Very High.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="6" %}
entry.summary: John Sample 11.06.2021 Adult Resilience Scale Client Report

entry.title: Adult Resilience Scale Coach Report
entry.content:
John Sample
11.06.2021

Adult Resilience Scale
Coach Report

{% include ars/header.html %}

Definition of
Resilience

Many people have encountered an adverse experience at some point in their lives. Yet, some bounce back quickly while others endure the negativity for a longer period. A distinguishing factor between these people is their level of resilience.

Resilience has been widely defined as the ability to adapt to the changing environment and to bounce back from adversity and personal setbacks. Resilience has also been recognised as a measure of stress and the ability to cope with negative events, and can thus be defined as the personal qualities that enable an individual to thrive in difficult circumstances.

Research suggests that resilient people adapt more successfully in response to major life events and traumatic experiences (Sarkar & Fletcher, 2014). Research also shows that resilience is not necessarily related to personality or intelligence (Carver & Connor-Smith, 2010).

Interpreting the Adult Resilience Scale Scores

This report is a confidential summary of the candidate’s responses to the Adult Resilience Scale, and provides descriptions to interpret the scores. The Adult Resilience Scale measures five dimensions of resilience and provides an overall Total Resilience Score. When interpreting the candidate’s results, it is important to remember that scores are neither good nor bad, and should be used as development opportunities.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="1" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Model of Resilience

The five dimensions of resilience as measured in the Adult Resilience Scale are as follows:

Threat Perception

Awareness of potential or actual threat and ability to formulate a plan.

Adjustment

Ability to adjust when unexpected events cause disruption.

Decision Making

Ability to make clear decisions during stressful situations.

Coping

Capacity to deal with stressful events and ability to return to normal routine.

Recovery

Speed of returning to normal activity after challenging situations.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="2" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Results for John Sample

Overview

{% include ars/result-bar.html title="Total Resilience" color="navy" display_score="282" max_score="300" percentage="94" extra_classes="ms-3 mb-12" %} {% include ars/result-bar.html title="Threat Perception" color="purple" display_score="39" max_score="60" percentage="65" extra_classes="ms-3 mb-12" %} {% include ars/result-bar.html title="Adjustment" color="orange" display_score="30" max_score="60" percentage="50" extra_classes="ms-3 mb-12" %} {% include ars/result-bar.html title="Decision Making" color="green" display_score="50" max_score="90" percentage="55.5" extra_classes="ms-3 mb-12" %} {% include ars/result-bar.html title="Coping" color="fuchsia" display_score="80" max_score="90" percentage="88.9" extra_classes="ms-3 mb-12" %} {% include ars/result-bar.html title="Recovery" color="yellow" display_score="80" max_score="90" percentage="88.9" extra_classes="ms-3 mb-12" %}
{% include ars/footer.html page_number="3" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Dimensions and Intervals

Total Resilience: 282

  • Ability to adapt.
  • Time needed to bounce back from adversity.
  • Capacity to cope with stress.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="navy" display_score="282" max_score="300" percentage="94" extra_classes="ms-3 mt-2 mb-15" %}
Very High Range: 244–300

This level of resilience indicates an exceptional level of ability to adapt to the changing environment and to bounce back from adversity and personal setbacks. Individuals with this level of resilience also have a very high capacity to cope with stress.

High Range: 221–243

Individuals with this level of resilience will be able to succeed when faced with significant challenges and serious problems, and have a high capacity to cope with stress.

Average Range: 175–220

Individuals with this level of resilience have a reasonable capacity to respond to difficult circumstances, to adapt to change and to cope in stressful situations.

Low Range: 152–174

Individuals with this level of resilience are likely to find it difficult to succeed when faced with significant challenges and serious problems. Individuals may be uncomfortable dealing with problems or stress, and are likely to find it difficult to bounce back from adversity and personal setbacks.

Very Low Range: 0–151

Individuals with this level of resilience may frequently find it difficult to progress and to improve their situation when faced with significant challenges. Individuals may be uncomfortable dealing with problems or stress.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="4" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Threat Perception: 39

  • Perceptive ability or situational awareness.
  • Awareness of potential or actual threat.
  • Ability to formulate a plan to continue.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="purple" display_score="39" max_score="60" percentage="65" extra_classes="ms-3 mt-2 mb-15" %}
Very High Range: 48–60

Individuals with this level of threat perception are very perceptive and acutely aware of their surrounding situation, especially recognising potential or actual problems or threats, and will very quickly formulate a recovery plan.

High Range: 44–47

Individuals with this level of threat perception are more aware of the surrounding environment than others. They will notice problems before they arise and will quickly plan a way forward.

Average Range: 34–43

Individuals with this level of threat perception have an average awareness of the environment and of potentially stressful situations. Individuals have the capacity to gradually work out a way forward.

Low Range: 29–33

Individuals with this level of threat perception may be less aware of the surrounding environment. Individuals may only notice problems after they arise.

Very Low Range: 0–28

Individuals with this level of threat perception are very slow to perceive problems in their surrounding environment. They will frequently not recognise potential problems, actual problems or threats. Individuals will very rarely be able to formulate a plan to continue.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="5" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Adjustment: 30

  • Ability to adjust when unexpected events cause disruption.
  • Assessment of recovery options.
  • Flexibility and openness to new circumstances.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="orange" display_score="30" max_score="60" percentage="50" extra_classes="ms-3 mt-2 mb-15" %}
Very High Range: 54–60

This level of adjustment indicates a very high ability to adjust to unexpected events that cause disruption, as well as a very high ability to assess subsequent recovery options. Individuals have a very high level of flexibility and openness to new circumstances.

High Range: 48–53

This level of adjustment indicates a high ability to adjust to unexpected events that cause disruption, as well as a high ability to assess subsequent recovery options. Individuals have a high level of flexibility and openness to new circumstances.

Average Range: 35–47

This level of adjustment capacity indicates an average ability to continue in the face of difficult circumstances. Individuals have an average ability to assess recovery options and have an average level of flexibility and openness to new circumstances. Individuals may be better than others at noticing when a new approach to a problem is needed.

Low Range: 29–34

This level of adjustment capacity indicates a low ability to continue in the face of difficult circumstances. Individuals have limited ability to assess recovery options and are rarely flexible or open to new circumstances.

Very Low Range: 0–28

This level of adjustment capacity indicates a very low ability to continue in the face of difficult circumstances. Individuals have a very limited ability to assess recovery options and are very rarely flexible or open to new circumstances.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="6" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Decision Making: 43

  • Ability to decide on recovery actions.
  • Capacity to make good decisions under pressure.
  • Capacity to make clear decisions in stressful events.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="green" display_score="43" max_score="60" percentage="71.7" extra_classes="ms-3 mt-2 mb-15" %}
Very High Range: 49–60

Individuals at this level of decision making have a very strong ability to make good decisions under pressure, and to determine recovery actions in the face of difficult circumstances. They have a very high ability to make clear decisions in stressful situations, to assess the available recovery options and to choose the best one.

High Range: 44–48

Individuals at this level of decision making have the capacity to make very good decisions under pressure. They have a high ability to make clear decisions in stressful situations, to assess the available recovery options, and to choose the best one.

Average Range: 32–43

Individuals at this level of decision making have an average ability to make good decisions under pressure. They can determine recovery actions in the face of difficult circumstances and make clear decisions when in stressful situations. Individuals can assess the available recovery options before choosing the best one.

Low Range: 27–31

Individuals at this level of decision making may have trouble making decisions under pressure. Individuals may find it difficult to assess the available options or to choose one that will help them recover quickly.

Very Low Range: 0–26

Individuals at this level of decision making have very limited ability to make good decisions under pressure and to determine recovery actions in the face of difficult circumstances. They have a poor ability to make clear decisions when in stressful situations. Individuals find it difficult to assess the available recovery options and to choose the best one.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="7" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Coping: 53

  • Capacity to deal with difficult issues.
  • Ability to put stressful events into perspective.
  • Capacity to activate coping mechanisms in a stressful event.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="fuchsia" display_score="53" max_score="60" percentage="88.3" extra_classes="ms-3 mt-2 mb-15" %}
Very High Range: 54–60

This level of coping capacity indicates a very high ability to deal with difficult issues as they arise, as well as a very high capacity to put stressful events into perspective. Individuals operate recovery coping mechanisms and accept that a change in approach or strategy is required, so that stressful events are less likely to have a negative impact. Individuals have a very high ability to act on decisions when under pressure and can readily apply the chosen solution to the problem.

High Range: 49–53

This level of coping capacity indicates a significant ability to deal with difficult issues as they arise, as well as a high capacity to put stressful events into perspective. Individuals operate recovery coping mechanisms and accept that a change in approach or strategy is required, so that stressful events are less likely to have a negative impact. Individuals may find it easier than others to act on decisions when under pressure and can easily apply the chosen solution to the problem.

Average Range: 38–48

Individuals within this range of coping have an average capacity to deal with difficult issues as they arise, to put stressful events into perspective and to operate recovery coping mechanisms. They have a reasonable ability to accept that a change in approach or strategy is required, so that stressful events are less likely to have a negative impact. Individuals can often apply the chosen solution to the problem.

Low Range: 32–37

Individuals have a limited capacity to deal with difficult issues as they arise and to put stressful events into perspective. They can sometimes operate recovery coping mechanisms and accept that a change in approach or strategy is required, so that stressful events are less likely to have a negative impact. Individuals can sometimes apply the chosen solution to the problem.

Very Low Range: 0–31

Individuals may find it more difficult than others to act on their decisions when under pressure. They may struggle to apply the chosen solution to the problem. Individuals sometimes require more time to rest and recover before trying to tackle the problem. Individuals may choose options that are easier to implement, even though they may not be the best solutions.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="8" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Recovery: 53

  • Ability to plan effectively.
  • Speed of self-management after a stressful event.
  • Return to healthy self after a stressful event.
{% include ars/result-bar.html title="no" color="yellow" display_score="53" max_score="60" percentage="88.3" extra_classes="ms-3 mt-2 mb-15" %}
Very High Range: 54–60

This level of recovery capacity indicates a very strong ability to plan effectively and to return to normal activity. Individuals recover very quickly after hardship or negative situations.

High Range: 47–53

This level of recovery capacity indicates a strong ability to plan effectively and to return to normal activity quickly after hardship or negative situations.

Average Range: 33–46

Individuals at this level of recovery may regain strength and resilience soon after problems are dealt with. Individuals have an average ability to plan effectively and to return to normal activity after hardship or negative situations.

Low Range: 26–32

This level of recovery capacity indicates a limited ability to plan effectively and to return to normal activity after hardship or negative situations.

Very Low Range: 0–25

This level of recovery capacity indicates a very limited ability to plan effectively and to return to normal activity after hardship or negative situations.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="9" %}
{% include ars/header.html %}

Adult Resilience Scale and Bell Curve Distribution

A bell curve is the informal name of a graph that depicts a normal probability distribution. The raw scores on the Adult Resilience Scale are best viewed in the below bell curve distribution. The bell curve represents a ‘normal distribution’ of the general population. A normal distribution has the average (or mean) centred and an equal distribution above and below average like the curve below. The bell curve assumes there is an equivalent number of people above and below average, and a very small number of people two standard deviations above and below the average (mean).

The raw scores on the Adult Resilience Scale are converted to mean (average) scores and standard deviations across five intervals ranging from Very Low, Low, Average, High, and Very High. For further information on scores and interpretation, refer to the Adult Resilience Scale Manual.

{% include ars/footer.html page_number="10" %}
entry.summary: John Sample 11.06.2021 Adult Resilience Scale Coach Report
